speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: SCENE I. Plains near Rome.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Enter LUCIUS with an army of Goths, with drum and colours

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Approved warriors, and my faithful friends,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I have received letters from great Rome,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Which signify what hate they bear their emperor

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And how desirous of our sight they are.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Therefore, great lords, be, as your titles witness,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Imperious and impatient of your wrongs,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And wherein Rome hath done you any scath,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Let him make treble satisfaction.

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: Brave slip, sprung from the great Andronicus,

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: Whose name was once our terror, now our comfort;

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: Whose high exploits and honourable deeds

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: Ingrateful Rome requites with foul contempt,

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: Be bold in us: we'll follow where thou lead'st,

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: Like stinging bees in hottest summer's day

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: Led by their master to the flowered fields,

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: And be avenged on cursed Tamora.

speaker: All the Goths
text_entry: And as he saith, so say we all with him.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I humbly thank him, and I thank you all.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: But who comes here, led by a lusty Goth?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Enter a Goth, leading AARON with his Child in his arms

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Renowned Lucius, from our troops I stray'd

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: To gaze upon a ruinous monastery;

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: And, as I earnestly did fix mine eye

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Upon the wasted building, suddenly

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: I heard a child cry underneath a wall.

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: I made unto the noise; when soon I heard

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: The crying babe controll'd with this discourse:

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: 'Peace, tawny slave, half me and half thy dam!

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Did not thy hue bewray whose brat thou art,

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Had nature lent thee but thy mother's look,

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Villain, thou mightst have been an emperor:

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: But where the bull and cow are both milk-white,

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: They never do beget a coal-black calf.

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Peace, villain, peace!'--even thus he rates

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: the babe,--

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: 'For I must bear thee to a trusty Goth;

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Who, when he knows thou art the empress' babe,

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Will hold thee dearly for thy mother's sake.'

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: With this, my weapon drawn, I rush'd upon him,

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Surprised him suddenly, and brought him hither,

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: To use as you think needful of the man.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: O worthy Goth, this is the incarnate devil

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That robb'd Andronicus of his good hand;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: This is the pearl that pleased your empress' eye,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And here's the base fruit of his burning lust.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Say, wall-eyed slave, whither wouldst thou convey

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: This growing image of thy fiend-like face?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Why dost not speak? what, deaf? not a word?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: A halter, soldiers! hang him on this tree.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And by his side his fruit of bastardy.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Touch not the boy; he is of royal blood.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Too like the sire for ever being good.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: First hang the child, that he may see it sprawl;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: A sight to vex the father's soul withal.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Get me a ladder.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: A ladder brought, which AARON is made to ascend

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Lucius, save the child,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And bear it from me to the empress.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: If thou do this, I'll show thee wondrous things,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That highly may advantage thee to hear:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: If thou wilt not, befall what may befall,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I'll speak no more but 'Vengeance rot you all!'

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Say on: an if it please me which thou speak'st

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Thy child shall live, and I will see it nourish'd.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: An if it please thee! why, assure thee, Lucius,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: 'Twill vex thy soul to hear what I shall speak;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: For I must talk of murders, rapes and massacres,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Acts of black night, abominable deeds,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Complots of mischief, treason, villanies

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Ruthful to hear, yet piteously perform'd:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And this shall all be buried by my death,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Unless thou swear to me my child shall live.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Tell on thy mind; I say thy child shall live.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Swear that he shall, and then I will begin.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Who should I swear by? thou believest no god:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That granted, how canst thou believe an oath?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: What if I do not? as, indeed, I do not;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Yet, for I know thou art religious

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And hast a thing within thee called conscience,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: With twenty popish tricks and ceremonies,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Which I have seen thee careful to observe,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Therefore I urge thy oath; for that I know

speaker: AARON
text_entry: An idiot holds his bauble for a god

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And keeps the oath which by that god he swears,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To that I'll urge him: therefore thou shalt vow

speaker: AARON
text_entry: By that same god, what god soe'er it be,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That thou adorest and hast in reverence,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To save my boy, to nourish and bring him up;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Or else I will discover nought to thee.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Even by my god I swear to thee I will.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: First know thou, I begot him on the empress.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: O most insatiate and luxurious woman!

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Tut, Lucius, this was but a deed of charity

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To that which thou shalt hear of me anon.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: 'Twas her two sons that murder'd Bassianus;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: They cut thy sister's tongue and ravish'd her

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And cut her hands and trimm'd her as thou saw'st.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: O detestable villain! call'st thou that trimming?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Why, she was wash'd and cut and trimm'd, and 'twas

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Trim sport for them that had the doing of it.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: O barbarous, beastly villains, like thyself!

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Indeed, I was their tutor to instruct them:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That codding spirit had they from their mother,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: As sure a card as ever won the set;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That bloody mind, I think, they learn'd of me,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: As true a dog as ever fought at head.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Well, let my deeds be witness of my worth.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I train'd thy brethren to that guileful hole

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Where the dead corpse of Bassianus lay:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I wrote the letter that thy father found

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And hid the gold within the letter mention'd,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Confederate with the queen and her two sons:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And what not done, that thou hast cause to rue,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Wherein I had no stroke of mischief in it?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I play'd the cheater for thy father's hand,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And, when I had it, drew myself apart

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And almost broke my heart with extreme laughter:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I pry'd me through the crevice of a wall

speaker: AARON
text_entry: When, for his hand, he had his two sons' heads;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Beheld his tears, and laugh'd so heartily,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That both mine eyes were rainy like to his :

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And when I told the empress of this sport,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: She swooned almost at my pleasing tale,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And for my tidings gave me twenty kisses.

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: What, canst thou say all this, and never blush?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Ay, like a black dog, as the saying is.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Art thou not sorry for these heinous deeds?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Ay, that I had not done a thousand more.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Even now I curse the day--and yet, I think,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Few come within the compass of my curse,--

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Wherein I did not some notorious ill,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: As kill a man, or else devise his death,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Ravish a maid, or plot the way to do it,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Accuse some innocent and forswear myself,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Set deadly enmity between two friends,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Make poor men's cattle break their necks;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Set fire on barns and hay-stacks in the night,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And bid the owners quench them with their tears.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Oft have I digg'd up dead men from their graves,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And set them upright at their dear friends' doors,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Even when their sorrows almost were forgot;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And on their skins, as on the bark of trees,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Have with my knife carved in Roman letters,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: 'Let not your sorrow die, though I am dead.'

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Tut, I have done a thousand dreadful things

speaker: AARON
text_entry: As willingly as one would kill a fly,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And nothing grieves me heartily indeed

speaker: AARON
text_entry: But that I cannot do ten thousand more.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Bring down the devil; for he must not die

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: So sweet a death as hanging presently.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: If there be devils, would I were a devil,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To live and burn in everlasting fire,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: So I might have your company in hell,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: But to torment you with my bitter tongue!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Sirs, stop his mouth, and let him speak no more.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Enter a Goth

speaker: Third Goth
text_entry: My lord, there is a messenger from Rome

speaker: Third Goth
text_entry: Desires to be admitted to your presence.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Let him come near.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Enter AEMILIUS

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Welcome, AEmilius what's the news from Rome?

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Lord Lucius, and you princes of the Goths,

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: The Roman emperor greets you all by me;

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: And, for he understands you are in arms,

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: He craves a parley at your father's house,

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Willing you to demand your hostages,

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: And they shall be immediately deliver'd.

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: What says our general?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: AEmilius, let the emperor give his pledges

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Unto my father and my uncle Marcus,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And we will come. March away.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Exeunt
